slides.title: Workflow Automation
slides.narration: Every repetitive task you do manually is time stolen from growing your business. Workflow automation handles the routine so you can focus on what matters. Let's automate your biggest time drains.

slides.title: What You'll Automate
slides.narration: We'll identify your best automation opportunities, build your first workflow step by step, test and refine until it works perfectly, then show you how to expand automation across your business.

slides.title: Step 1: Find Opportunities

good_candidates: Same action triggered by same event
examples: Invoice paid → Send thank you + request review

slides.narration: Find automation opportunities. Good candidates: same action triggered by same event, multi-step processes you do frequently, tasks following consistent rules, data entry between systems. Examples: new inquiry triggers welcome email, booking triggers confirmation and reminder sequence, payment triggers thank you and review request.

slides.title: Step 2: Build the Workflow
slides.narration: Build your workflow with three components. Trigger: what starts it—like a form submission. Conditions: optional filters for when it should run—like only for consultation requests. Actions: what happens automatically—send email, create calendar hold, notify team, add to CRM. One trigger can kick off multiple actions.

slides.title: Step 3: Test Thoroughly
slides.narration: Test thoroughly before going live. Run with test data first. Check that each action completed correctly. Verify timing between steps is right. Test edge cases—what if a field is empty? Monitor the first ten real triggers to catch any issues. Better to find problems in testing than with real customers.

slides.title: Step 4: Expand and Optimize
slides.narration: Once your first workflow runs smoothly, expand. Customer onboarding sequences. Follow-up after service completion. Re-engagement campaigns for inactive customers. Optimized review request timing. Recurring appointment reminders. Track hours saved per workflow—most businesses save ten to fifteen hours weekly with five to seven automations.

slides.title: Pro Tips

tips: Start with one workflow, master it, then add more
Add delays between actions (feels more human)
Include error notifications so you know if something breaks

slides.narration: Automation pro tips. Start with one workflow, master it, then add more. Add delays between actions—immediate feels robotic, spaced out feels human. Include error notifications so you know if something breaks. Review automations quarterly as your business evolves.

slides.title: Start Automating
slides.narration: Ready to reclaim your time? Build your first workflow now. Or browse templates for common automations you can activate immediately. Every hour you automate is an hour you get back.
